RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN

Tesoro Golden Eagle Refinery

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies


Tesoro is an independent oil refiner and marketer of petroleum products in the United States.  Tesoro purchased the Golden Eagle Refinery in May, 2002.  

Tesoro's commitment to Health, Safety and the Environment begins at the corporate level.  The corporate safety statement sets the tone for this commitment.
Company assets will be maintained and operated in a manner consistent with maintaining a high standard in the areas of process safety, worker health and safety, community health and safety, and environmental stewardship.  Continuous improvement in EH&S performance will be pursued and incorporated into plans, goals and compensation decisions.  Reporting, tracking, and auditing requirements will be adhered to and all communication will be in accordance with the Company's core values of honesty and integrity.
Objectives:
* Ensure safe work environments for employees, contractors and visitors.
* Pursue continuous improvement of the Company's process safety, worker health and safety, and environmental performance.
* Pursue continuous improvement in minimizing impacts to the community and the environment that may result from the Company's operations, products or services.
* Communicate information pertinent to process safety, worker health and safety, and environmental matters to internal and external stakeholders.
* Integrate process safety, worker health and safety, and environmental considerations into operating and business decision-making processes.
* Conduct assessments to verify compliance with regulatory requirements, Company standards and accepted industry practices.

Tesoro has personnel at the corporate level dedicated to Environmental, Health and Safety.  However, current organization structure places primary responsibility for health, safety, and the environment within each of the major facilities.  Each major facility

e development and implementation of a Mechanical Integrity Program to proactively address maintenance of process equipment.  The program should include development of written procedures, training of maintenance personnel, inspection and testing of equipment, process for equipment repair and a method for assuring quality of process repair and construction.

The refinery's Mechanical Integrity Program addresses the integrity of process equipment and instrumentation for safe and reliable operations.  The refinery maintenance program covers three types of maintenance:  1) preventative and predictive maintenance, 2) routine maintenance (repair or corrective maintenance), and 3) turnarounds.  Preventative maintenance is performance of equipment inspection and repair based on time and historical knowledge of the equipment.  Predictive maintenance involves utilizing technological methods of inspection to determine equipment condition.  Preventative and predictive maintenance used in combination determine the inspection and repair frequency of equipment at the refinery.  Routine maintenance is the repair or corrective maintenance of equipment as dictated by predictive maintenance, preventative maintenance and equipment condition.  A turnaround is maintenance of a process unit on a large scale.  A turnaround is the periodic shutdown of a processing unit for cleaning, internal inspection and renewal.  The process unit is opened up and its critical components are inspected and repaired during a turnaround.  The goal of the Mechanical Integrity Program is to eliminate or minimize process chemical releases by maintaining the equipment.  


Predictive and Preventative Maintenance

Fixed Equipment:

The Metallurgical Engineering and Inspection (ME&I) Department has trained inspectors for performing inspections on fixed equipment at the refinery.  Fixed equipment includes, but is not limited to equipment such as pressure relief systems, fractionators, reactors, separators,

drums, strippers, tanks, exchangers, condensers, piping, structural equipment, etc.  The ME&I Department maintains a current list of all fixed equipment, categorized by process, which includes information on the last inspection, next planned inspection and inspection frequency.  Records of all equipment inspection are retained for the life of the equipment.  The ME&I Department also has a written procedures manual, which contains up-to-date written details on how to perform certain inspection techniques used to determine equipment serviceability.  Examples of techniques used by Inspectors include:  visual weld inspection, dry magnetic particle testing, wet fluorescent magnetic particle testing, liquid penetrant examination, Eddy current tube examination, IRIS tube inspection, ultrasonic testing, and radiographic viewing.  The ME&I Manual also details procedures regarding how to perform an inspection for certain pieces of equipment.  Examples include instructions on how to inspect piping, boilers, air receivers, pressure vessels, furnaces, and exchanger tube bundles.  Inspection frequency and methods of inspection are performed according to Industry Codes and Standards (refer to Process Safety Information for a listing of organizations that publish these standards) and the California State (Cal-OSHA) Safety Orders.  For example, pressure vessel inspection is performed according to API Standard 510.  The Inspection Procedures are reviewed regularly for accuracy.  Any changes to Inspection Procedures are managed through a revision process for tracking changes.  The Inspection Procedures Manual is available to employees both electronically through a computer shared-drive and in hard copy at their office.  


Rotating Equipment:

The Rotating Equipment Department performs all inspections and repairs on rotating equipment at the refinery.  Rotating equipment includes pumps, compressors, fans, blowers, turbines, engines, gear boxes, motors, etc.  The rotating equipmen

has comprehensive programs and policies for addressing these areas.  The Golden Eagle Refinery has its own mission statement, core values and Environmental, Health and Safety Rule and Standing Instruction (R&SI). The Golden Eagle Refinery mission statement sets the tone for the commitment to the environment, health and safety.
We will be the best refinery in California as viewed by our employees, our community and our customers.  Safety, respect for the environment, and operational excellence are key to our success.  We recognize the professional and personal needs of our employees and will maintain an environment in which excellence can be achieved.  We will positively impact the community in which we operate.  The decisions we make will be aligned with our core values.

The Golden Eagle Refinery has five fundamental values to guide everyone in adhering to the refinery mission statement.  They are:
* Safety
* Environment
* Reliability
* Integrity
* Profitability

The Golden Eagle Refinery also has an established Environmental, Health and Safety R&SI.  It is reproduced here in its entirety.

Rule and Standing Instruction

Management of the Golden Eagle Refinery is committed to a safe and environmentally compliant operation.  Within this firm commitment, management will ensure that systems are in place to train employees in safe and environmentally compliant operating practices and we will conduct operations to safeguard the environment and the health and safety of employees, contractors, customers, and the public. 

All employees and contractors are essential to this team effort and must conduct themselves in a safe and responsible manner.  Every employee and contractor is responsible for Environmental and Health and Safety compliance and will be properly trained and equipped for this role.

This Rule and Standing Instruction is founded on the following principles:
* We will ensure training of all employees and contractors on the safe work pract

ices of the Refinery.
* We will operate to meet or exceed applicable environmental and regulatory requirements.
* All employees are responsible for environmental and health and safety compliance.
* We will consistently review and improve our environmental, health and safety practices and promote employee engagement in practice development and training.
* We will include environmental, health, and safety considerations in every aspect of our business.
Should any employee or contractor become aware of any practices, conditions, or information that they believe to be contrary to these commitments, they must inform their supervisor or Tesoro contact.  Further, every Tesoro employee is obligated to report and assure follow-up on anything that indicates a lack of full commitment to the safe and environmentally compliant operation of the Refinery.

The essential goal at the Golden Eagle Refinery is to: provide an injury free work environment, operate at the pleasure of the community, and comply with all environmental regulations.

The Golden Eagle Refinery has both Health and Safety and Environmental Departments dedicated to ensuring compliance with applicable regulations.  The refinery has comprehensive safety programs to address the federal and state regulations discussed in this document as well as all other applicable Cal-OSHA, OSHA and local regulations.  The purpose of these programs are to: 

* provide a healthy and safe work environment, 
* ensure safe work performance for all operations, 
* establish and maintain a system to anticipate, recognize, evaluate and control occupational Health and Safety hazards,
* provide employees with appropriate information, training and protective equipment relating to potential Health and Safety hazards associated with their job assignments, and
* comply with all applicable local, state and federal regulations.

The Environmental Compliance Program includes a refinery R&SI on environmental compliance and reporting

, which clearly states that each employee has a responsibility to help protect the environment by complying with established policies and procedures.  This includes knowing the environmental limits of units and a responsibility to report all leaks.

The Program 3 Prevention Program Elements, discussed in this Risk Management Plan (RMP), are one part of the overall safety program at the Golden Eagle Refinery.  Each program element is assigned to appropriate personnel, who have the responsibility for implementing each element in a manner consistent with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program Guidance Document developed by Contra Costa Health Services.  The program elements are assigned as follows:  The PHA coordinator is responsible for Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), Management of Change (MOC) and Pre Start-Up Safety Review (PSSR) program elements.  The Design Department in Engineering is responsible for the Process Safety Information (PSI) program element.  Personnel in the Health and Safety Department have responsibility for Hot Work, Contractors, Incident Investigation, Compliance Audits, Emergency Response, and Employee Participation.  Operating Procedures and Training (for Operators) is the responsibility of the Operations Departments.  Training for maintenance employees is the responsibility of the Maintenance Department.  Mechanical Integrity is jointly owned between Engineering and Maintenance Departments.  Senior Management has overall responsibility for the Safety Program management.  Personnel who have responsibility of the elements periodically evaluate the effectiveness of the program, through an internal audit, and make changes as the need arises.  Senior Staff also periodically reviews each program for effectiveness.  In addition, Senior Management sets goals and objectives for each program to provide guidance for responsible personnel about expectations for each program.

The Refinery R&SI Manual contains all the R&SI pertain

bution system for repair.  The Motor Management program addresses motor reliability.  The transformer program includes inspection and testing of transformers.  The UPS/Battery Program requires quarterly testing of these power sources.  The Substation and Switching Station Program addresses inspection and testing of electrical power distribution stations to ensure reliability.  The Insulator Washing Program covers the cleaning of high voltage insulators.  The Pole Inspection Program covers annual inspection of all power poles in the refinery.  The Analyzer Program covers calibration and testing of analyzers; the results of the tests are tracked by computer to predict maintenance requirements.  The Vibration Program is performed on motors with the Rotating Equipment Group.  The Cathodic Protection System is checked through a monthly inspection program.  Control valves are serviced through a Control Valve Management Plan, where a flow-scanning system is used to quantify and record the control valve performance.  The Relief Valve Servicing program covers refinery pressure relief systems.  The Safety Instrumented System (SIS) program addresses inspection, testing and repair of critical instrumentation.  In addition, the Distributed Control System (DCS) Technicians inspect and test the computer systems that control refinery processes.  The test frequencies are specified by instrumentation type and manufacturer specifications.  Inspection and test records are maintained on file and tracked by database.  I&E has written procedures for performing inspections and tests.  These procedures are reviewed regularly; changes are tracked through a revision process.  Due to the rapid technological expansion occurring in instrumentation and digital control systems, I&E has more frequent personnel training and procedure reviews than other areas.  


Repair

Routine or corrective maintenance of equipment is performed by experienced Craftspeople.  Craft specialties include Boilermak

ers, Welders, Pipefitters, Exchanger Shop Mechanics, Mechanics, Machinists, Riggers, Carpenters/Builders, Compressor Mechanics, Valve Mechanics, Instrument Mechanics, Electricians and DCS Technicians.  Corrective maintenance is performed on equipment as dictated by predictive maintenance, preventative maintenance and equipment condition.  Operator surveillance during their routine inspections of the units is also used for determining the need for repair of equipment.  Documentation of repairs is developed and maintained in the applicable equipment folders for the life of the equipment.  The repairs may be performed in maintenance shops or in the field.  The refinery has specialized repair shops for carpenter work, welding, machine work, instrument and electrical repair, and exchanger repair.  Inspectors perform inspections and tests on fixed equipment and maintenance craft personnel perform the repairs.  These repairs are typically performed in the field.  The Maintenance Department has written procedures for corrective maintenance of equipment.  These procedures are available on the refinery intranet as well as in hard copy.  Rotating equipment is both inspected and repaired by Rotating Equipment Department personnel.  These repairs may be performed in a shop or in the field by Machinists or Machinery Field Specialists.  The Rotating Equipment Department has written procedures for repair of the equipment.  These procedures are reviewed annually and tracked through a revision process.  I&E repairs electrical equipment, instrumentation and relief valves.  These repairs may be performed in the shop or in the field by the appropriate Craftspeople.  I&E has written procedures for repair of their equipment.  These procedures are regularly reviewed and changes are tracked through a revision process.  

Repair work is planned by maintenance planners.  They develop detailed plans for conducting repairs in a safe manner.  Depending upon the scope of work, the proper inform

ation and materials are assembled for the repair work to proceed.  In addition, the appropriate safe work permit requirements are identified for the job.  Upon completion, repair records for equipment specific repairs are retained in hard copy or tracked by computer database.


Turnaround

A turnaround is maintenance of a process unit on a large scale.  A turnaround is the periodic shutdown of a processing unit for the cleaning, inspection and renewal of parts.  The process unit is opened up and its critical components are inspected and repaired during a turnaround.  Due to the  of the project, turnarounds take 6-24 months of planning.  Three criteria determine the frequency of unit turnarounds; they are:  the type of unit, the history of the unit and specific government regulations.  Typically, units undergo turnaround every two to five years.  Large unit turnarounds may require the use of 1000 contract craftspeople to complete the repairs.

The refinery employs experienced Journey-level Craftspeople in a number of disciplines to perform maintenance at the refinery.  Craft disciplines include Boilermakers, Welders, Transportation (drivers), Pipefitters, Exchanger Shop Mechanics, Mechanics, Machinists, Vibration Specialists, Riggers, Carpenters/Builders, Compressor Mechanics, Valve Mechanics, Instrument Mechanics and Electricians.  The refinery hires only Journey-level craftspeople; all Craftspeople must pass a written and practical exam to demonstrate their skills prior to hire. These training modules may include, but are not limited to:  forklift operations, respirator fit testing, fresh air, blinding, torqueing, hose use/selection, gasket selection, fall protection, lead abatement, asbestos, lock-out/tag-out, hazardous energy, confined space, hot work,

ing to safety and environmental performance.  Each member of Senior Management is ultimately responsible for each policy in the Policies and Procedures Manual.  In addition to the policies discussed above, the Policies and Procedures Manual contains emergency response policies. Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled


Stationary Source Description:

The Tesoro Golden Eagle Refinery processes approximately 160,000 barrels (1 barrel equals 42 gallons) of crude oil per day into transportation fuels.  The principal fuels produced are gasoline and diesel.  The refinery produces Propane and Butane for commercial purposes.  In addition, the refinery produces anhydrous Ammonia and elemental Sulfur for the agricultural market, as well as petroleum coke used for fuel in cogeneration plants in East Contra Costa County and overseas.  The refinery also supplies Carbon Dioxide to Air Liquide for the manufacture of dry ice.  The refinery accomplishes the production of these products from crude oil through the use of many complex processing units.  The refinery processes San Joaquin Valley Crude, Alaskan North Slope Crude and a large variety of other crudes.  San Joaquin Valley Crude is an example of a heavy oil, rich in sulfur and nitrogen.  Heavy oils must be converted to lighter hydrocarbons in order for it to be useable as motor fuels.  In addition, the sulfur and nitrogen must be removed from the oil distillates during processing to produce motor fuels that produce less smog upon combustion by cars and trucks.  Alaskan North Slope Crude, an example of a lighter crude, also must undergo similar processing to produce motor fu

els.

Crude Oil begins its journey through the refinery at the Crude Units.  Desalters dehydrate the oil and remove salts electrically to reduce the oil's corrosivity.  It is then sent to the distillation tower where the hydrocarbons are heated and separated into fractions by molecular weight.  Lighter hydrocarbons have lower boiling points than heavier hydrocarbons.  The distillation tower produces six fractions:  wet gas/butanes, gasoline, naphtha, kerosene, gas oil and resid.  The heaviest component, resid, is sent to the Feed Prep units for further distillation under vacuum.  After vacuum distillation,  the Feed Prep bottom product, which is made up of very heavy hydrocarbons and is solid at ambient temperature,  is sent to the Delayed Coker Unit (DCU).  The DCU thermally cracks large molecules  into smaller ones.  These smaller molecules can then be further processed into motor fuels.  The DCU also produces petroleum coke, which is black carbon powder.

The gas oil fractions from the Crude Units, the Feed Prep Units, and the Coker are still too heavy for use as motor fuels.  These fractions are catalytically cracked in the Fluid Catalytic Cracking Unit (FCCU) and/or the Hydrocracker Unit.  Both of these units crack the hydrocarbon molecules into smaller molecules in the presence of a catalyst.  Catalytic cracking is more selective than thermal cracking.  The FCCU cracking breaks long chain hydrocarbons into short chains and multi-ring compounds into smaller ring compounds.  In addition, olefin compounds (unsaturated hydrocarbons) are generated.  Olefins are undesirable in motor fuels because they contribute to the formation of smog during engine combustion.  The olefins are removed by other process units.  The cracking process in the Hydrocracker occurs in the presence of Hydrogen gas.  Olefins and other unsaturated compounds are saturated during the hydrocracking process in addition to breaking larger chain or ringed hydrocarbons into smaller compounds.

The Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) units remove sulfur and nitrogen from their feedstocks, creating Hydrogen Sulfide and Ammonia, which are separated and processed elsewhere.  These units also saturate olefins.  The HDS units are particularly important for ensuring cleaner burning gasoline, since the removal of these compounds is critical to preventing smog from engine combustion of gasoline and diesel.  The Hydrodearomatization (HDA) unit removes aromatic compounds from diesel fractions, a necessary step in the production of producing cleaner burning fuels.  The Reformer rearranges hydrocarbons from straight chains into branched chains, rings and aromatics; these compounds are desirable because they raise the octane number of the motor fuels.  Aromatic compounds created by the Reforming units are saturated in the Benzene Saturation Unit, ensuring their removal from clean fuel production.  The Alkylation Unit combines two small molecules, a branched hydrocarbon and an olefin, to make a larger branched hydrocarbon.  This process generates alkylate, which is a high octane blending component in gasoline.  The Alkylation Unit uses Sulfuric Acid as a catalyst, which is an inherently safer alternative to Hydrofluoric Acid.  

The cracking processes produce very small hydrocarbons as well as the larger fractions discussed above.  The #1, #4, and #5 Gas Plants and the Light Hydrocarbon Fractionation (#1ISOM) purify these compounds.  The smallest molecules (one and two carbons) are used in the refinery for fuel.  The propanes and butanes are used as feedstocks for the Alkylation process and for commercial sale.  

The refinery has two boilers that produce high pressure, high temperature steam, which is used for both heating and cooling various processes.  The Water Treatment Plants (WTP) produce high quality water for use in the boilers and process cooling systems.  The API Separator and the Waste Water Treatment (WWT) plant are part of the refinery's waste water treatmen

repacking valves, rebuilding site glasses, bleeder reamer use, turbine repair, laser alignment of equipment, staging/scaffolding, rigging/crane, highlift, and leak repair.  During the lock-out/tag-out training module, there is an emphasis on understanding the hazardous energy sources.  All Craftspeople must complete an exam at the conclusion of each training module.  Vibration Specialists responsible for performing predictive and preventative maintenance on rotating equipment have been certified in their craft by attending in-depth training courses from the Vibration Institute and/or manufacturers' training courses.  Machinists who perform vibration analysis on rotating equipment have received 12 hours of classroom training in addition to field training.  The instrument mechanics and electricians have skills training annually, including a specialized CBT for their craft.  Under special circumstances in 1999, all refinery Maintenance Craftspeople repeated all training modules described above (with the exception of vibration training).  Training records have been retained since the inception of the PSM regulation in 1992.   


Inspector Training:

Inspectors perform inspections of structures and fixed equipment to ensure the safety of personnel and property.  The inspection personnel receive specialized training to assure that they are able to successfully perform their job.  All Inspectors must have five years experience in operations, welding and/or boilermaker craft.  They must pass a written exam as well as a vision test.  The Inspector initially is trained in a company developed training program involving in-house and off-site training.  The course curriculum is focused on non-destructive testing and equipment visual inspection.  Specific courses may include:  Introduction to non-destructive testing, visual weld inspection, radiation safety and radiographic examination, math and physics for industrial technology, ASME pressure vessel and boiler codes, magnet

ic particle examination, ultrasonic examination-thickness gauging, color contact penetrant examination, API 510 on pressure vessels, API 570 on piping and API 653 on tanks.  Certification of course completion is performed by written exam.  All training is paid for by the refinery.  The Inspector training is compliant with ASNT SNT-TC-1A and API guidelines.  Recertification, as specified in ASNT SNT-TC-1A and API guidelines, occurs every 3 to 5 years depending on the method and/or certification.  Inspector training is tracked by the Inspection Department by database, including when training has been completed and refresher training is due.  In addition, hard copies of all Inspector certification are kept on file.  Training records have been retained since the inception of the PSM regulation in 1992.

General Safety Refresher Training:

In addition, all Maintenance Craftspeople and Inspectors must complete an annual CBT and classroom training that addresses chemical hazards, the emergency action plan, electrical safety awareness, safe work permitting, PPE, and respiratory protection.  The training records of all maintenance personnel except ME&I, are kept by the Training department.  


Quality Assurance:

The quality of maintenance repair work on fixed equipment is verified by Inspectors.  The Inspectors perform or oversee specific tests after the repair is complete to assure that the repair has been performed properly and with appropriate materials.  The nature of the tests used for quality assurance depends upon the type of work performed and is typically specified by an Inspector.  To assure the proper material has been used in building or repairing a process, the refinery has a Positive Materials Identification Procedure.  This procedure involves the use of an analyzer capable of identifying metal alloys.  Rotating equipment quality assurance is performed by Supervisors.  They perform visual inspections, pressure testing (where and when applicable) and s

tart-up checks.  In addition, spare parts original manufacturer's number is tracked along with the manufacturer provided documentation (material certification papers) to ensure the right parts have been installed into the proper service.  Instrument and Electrical repair quality is assured by strict use of original equipment manufacturer spare parts.  Repair of relief valves are performed by VR qualified shops, these specialized shops have been certified by a national board to perform work on relief valves.  


Management of Change

Federal, state and local regulations require the development and implementation of written procedures to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  The Management of Change (MOC) procedure must address the technical basis for the change, the impact on health and safety, modifications to operating procedures, time period for the change and authorization for the change.  Training of employees must be conducted prior to start-up of the process if the change affects their job task.  In addition, any changes to PSI or operating procedures require these items be updated.  

The purpose of the MOC program is to ensure that modifications to processes are properly evaluated and documented with the same degree of scrutiny as the original process design.  Changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures are managed through the MOC process.  Replacements in kind, which are changes to components that are within current design specifications, are not subject to the MOC program.  Procedure changes are managed through a revision process; the other types of changes listed above proceed through the process described below.  Although this document discusses the MOC and PSSR programs separately, these two programs are inextricably linked in practice.  This program is beneficial for release prevention because it provides a process for review of changes and their potential effects prior to their impleme

t system.  The water that is removed from crude oil prior to processing and water from other process stages is treated by separation and biological conversion systems prior to its permitted discharge.  The Sour Water Stripper (a.k.a. the Foul Water Stripper) is also part of the waste water treating system and removes Hydrogen Sulfide from sour water streams.  

The sulfur and nitrogen removed from processing streams is converted into anhydrous Ammonia and elemental Sulfur at the Chemical Plant.  The Chemical Plant actually consists of five units, the Ammonia Recovery Unit (ARU), Acid Plant, Diethanolamine (DEA) Stripping Unit, Sulfur Recovery Unit (SRU) and a Shell Claus Offgas Treating (SCOT) Unit.  The ARU removes Ammonia and Hydrogen Sulfide from refinery sour water streams.  The Ammonia is then purified for agricultural purposes, while the Hydrogen Sulfide is sent to the SRU.  The Acid Plant recycles the spent Sulfuric Acid from the Alkylation Unit for its reuse.  The DEA stripping unit removes Hydrogen Sulfide from refinery DEA streams as part of the sulfur recovery process.  The SRU converts collected Hydrogen Sulfide into saleable elemental sulfur.  The SCOT plant receives and treats sulfur-containing tailgas from the SRU, converts the sulfur containing compounds to Hydrogen Sulfide and returns the stream to the SRU for reprocessing.

Description of Regulated Substances:

Most of the regulated substances handled at the refinery regulated by the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program and EPA's Risk Management Program are flammables.  These materials range in flammability from Pentane (with a flash point greater than -40? F) to Hydrogen (with a flash point of -100? F).  For reference, a flash point is defined as the lowest temperature at which a liquid will give off sufficient vapor to ignite on application of a flame.  Larger flash points indicate less flammability.  Materials with low flash points must be handled carefully and isolate

d from ignition sources to prevent fires or explosions involving these compounds.  For comparison, gasoline has a flash point of -45? F and diesel fuel has a flash point of 125? F.  Propane and Butane are flammable gasses with flash points lower than gasoline. 

As part of refining crude oil to motor fuels, other regulated substances are generated in addition to the flammables.  The four materials discussed here are hazardous principally through inhalation.  Hydrogen Sulfide, with its characteristic rotten egg odor, is created in the processing units that remove sulfur and nitrogen from the refining streams.  Hydrogen Sulfide is a colorless, corrosive, toxic gas; its odor can be readily detected at concentrations below concern.  Hydrogen Sulfide is not stored at the refinery.  As soon as it is generated, it is immediately sent to the Chemical Plant for processing into elemental Sulfur or Sulfuric Acid.  Ammonia is also created by the same processing units.  Ammonia is a colorless, corrosive, toxic gas with a sharp irritating odor.  Its odor is also readily detectable at concentrations below concern.  Ammonia is sent to the Chemical Plant where it is purified into Anhydrous Ammonia, stored in tanks and shipped to agricultural suppliers.  Sulfur Dioxide is a colorless, corrosive, toxic gas with an irritating pungent odor that can be perceived as burnt matches.  Sulfur Dioxide's odor also allows it to be detected at low concentrations.  Sulfur Dioxide is not stored at the Chemical Plant; it is an intermediate in the Sulfuric Acid Recycling process.  Oleum is concentrated Sulfuric Acid with Sulfur Trioxide dissolved in it, hence its nickname Fuming Sulfuric Acid.  Sulfur Trioxide is a toxic gas with a sharp odor, it also is an intermediate in the Sulfuric Acid Recycling process.


Covered Processes:

The Covered Processes for the refinery are listed in the data sheets.


Worst-Case Release Scenarios and Alternative Release Scenarios

The Golden Eagle Ref

inery has both Program Level 1 and Program Level 3 Covered Processes as defined by EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program regulations.  A Program Level 1 process is a process that contains at least the threshold quantity of a regulated substance, the Worst Case Scenario (WCS) does not go offsite, and has had no incidents meeting the CalARP reporting requirements.  A Program Level 3 process is a process that contains at least the threshold quantity of a regulated substance and the WCS reaches an offsite receptor.  A Worst Case Scenario (WCS) is a hypothetical event and the parameters for calculating the WCS is defined in the regulations.  For calculation purposes, it is assumed that the entire contents of the regulated substance in the largest container is released.  For Flammable scenarios, it is assumed all the material explodes.  For Toxic scenarios, it is assumed that the whole container is released within a ten minute period.  Based on these mathematical assumptions, a distance can be calculated for the WCS.  The WCS and Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS) are not discussed in the executive summary for security reasons.


General Accidental Release Prevention Program/Chemical-Specific Prevention


Management Systems

The Golden Eagle Refinery has implemented a management system for developing and continually improving the risk management program elements.  The Health and Safety Manager has the overall responsibility for the management of the risk management program elements.  An organizational chart showing the responsible parties for each risk management element is attached below.  The CalARP compliance program is incorporated as part of the refinery's Process Safety Management (PSM) compliance.  PSM is a Cal-OSHA regulation addressing process safety at industrial facilities.  CalARP and PSM regulations are similar in their requirements.  PSM was enacted earlier than CalARP, PSM directed tha

ntation in the process.

Any change that alters the design specification of the process must have a MOC performed.  To initiate the MOC process, a MOC form is completed.  This form describes the change, the justification for the change, the level of scrutiny required for the MOC process and PSSR, PHA requirements, and training requirements of personnel.  The design basis for the change must be attached to the form.  The MOC may then be reviewed by any or all of the following disciplines:  Health and Safety, Environmental, or Engineering in the areas of process, mechanical, electrical, instrument control, civil, metallurgy, rotating equipment or design engineering (the Health and Safety Review form is mandatory).  The MOC form has sections for personnel in the reviewing disciplines to identify necessary actions to allow this change to occur.  The actions can fall into any of seven areas:  process technology (PSI is included here), equipment/inspection, rotating equipment, instrumentation/controls, electrical, unit records and procedures/training.  

The Health and Safety Review of the MOC form consists of a checklist that evaluated the areas of industrial hygiene, emergency response, field safety and regulatory compliance.  The industrial hygiene checklist covers adequacy of PPE and any personnel monitoring, while the emergency response checklist examines the adequacy of the fire protection equipment and emergency response procedures as they pertain to the change.  Field safety covers adequacy of safety showers, eyewash stations and chemical containment.  Regulatory compliance covers the need for any changes to RMP or Hazardous Materials Business Plan due to the MOC.  A PHA is performed on changes of greater complexity because more scrutiny is required on more complex changes.  The Environmental Department also reviews MOCs with a checklist.  Their checklist examines if the change will increase odors, change air emissions or fugitive emissions, impact effluent wa

ter quality, impact groundwater quality, impact any ecological areas, increase hazardous waste generation or require permits.

The MOC is deemed complete when all necessary analysis, work completion, training and document updating has been completed.  Upon completion of the MOC, the Area Supervisor authorizes the completion of the MOC along with the approval of the PHA Coordinator.

Temporary changes are those changes that are expected to exist for a limited period or a change that is being evaluated on a trial basis.  If temporary changes are required, a temporary end date is noted on the MOC form.  At the time of the end of that time, the technical evaluator must confirm that the change has been returned to original conditions, extend the temporary end date, or go through the process to make the change permanent.  

Employee/Contractor training on the change typically takes place at safety meetings or one-on-one meetings with the supervisor.  In addition, control rooms have MOC binders/log for operators to read as part of the shift change routine.  If changes involve procedures, supervisors are responsible for ensuring that their employees are trained and understand the new procedure.  This may involve one-on-one discussions or practical demonstration.  If PSI updates are required, the marked up PSI is given to the Design Group in Engineering.  The Design personnel then verifies the change prior to changing the PSI.  MOC records are retained for at least 5 years for their use in the revalidation of process PHAs.

MOC for organizational changes is specified under the Human Factors portion of Ordinance 98-48.  The purpose of this procedure is to provide a systematic method for evaluating potential health and safety consequences of changes in permanent staffing levels or reorganization in operations, emergency response or other Health and Safety positions, and to provide recommendations to assist in the safe, efficient and effective implementation of the chan

ge.  Examples of changes that would require this use of this procedure are reorganization of Health, Safety and Emergency Response Departments, moving job duties from one department to another (such as from Operations to Health and Safety), and reduction in permanent staffing levels in Operations, Health and Safety and Emergency Response.


Pre Start-up Safety Reviews

Federal, state and local regulations require the performance of a Pre Start-up Safety Review prior to starting any new process or any changes to processes where PSI documents were revised.  The Pre Start-up Safety Review is a confirmation that the construction and equipment was installed according to design specifications, that safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures in place are adequate, any necessary PHAs have been performed, and that employee training has been completed.

The purpose of the Pre Start-up Safety Review (PSSR) program is for Operations to verify that elements required for the operation of new processes or changes to processes have been addressed prior to start-up.  The PSSR examines if the facilities have been engineered and constructed in accordance with the design, operating procedures are complete, personnel responsible for operating and maintaining the process have been appropriately notified or trained and that all applicable documentation is up-to-date and accessible.  Although this document discusses the MOC and PSSR programs separately, these two programs are inextricably linked in practice. The PSSR program is beneficial for accident release prevention because it provides a process for operations to confirm that a new process of modified process is safe to start.

All new processes and changes to a process that meet MOC criteria must go through the PSSR process.  The PSSR process confirms that all MOC signoffs are complete and that any pre start-up deficiencies have been resolved.  The PSSR process includes:  confirmation that the facilities have bee

t compliance development began in 1992, with completion in 1996.  However, CalARP directed that compliance development begin in 1996 with completion in 1999.  Development of the CalARP compliance program was the incorporation of any additional CalARP requirements into the already existing PSM compliance program.  




Each program element implementation is discussed in detail under the specific element sections (see Program 3 Prevention Elements).  Each element section also discusses the record retention requirements of that element.  While Senior Management has overall responsibility for the management of the risk management elements, personnel who have the responsibility of the elements periodically evaluate the effectiveness of their program, through an internal audit, and make changes as the need arises.  Senior Staff also periodically reviews each program for effectiveness.  Senior Management sets goals and objectives for each program to provide guidance for responsible personnel about expectations for each program.  In addition, guidance from regulatory agencies provide standards for the program elements.  Each program element is integrated into the overall organization of the refinery.  Any changes to the program are communicated through a variety of methods.  Communication between the element stewards is encouraged and expected for changes that could impact other element areas.  Changes will also be communicated through the Management Chain to all parties affected.  In addition, if the program change is significant, the changes will be communicated to all personnel at the refinery through any number of communication channels, such as email, bulletin board postings, hard copy distribution, safety meetings, etc.

Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Refineries have a number of safeguards that are used to protect personnel and property from the hazards of a Covered Process.  These safeguards were either originally constructed in the unit or implemented

as a recommendation from a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), Compliance Audit, and/or Incident Investigation.  Safeguards are examined during a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) by the PHA team for their adequacy in detecting, preventing and/or mitigating any potential hazards of the process.  If a PHA team determines that the safeguards do not adequately protect against a particular hazard, they recommend additional safeguards to the process.

As part of the PHA study, potential hazards and their safeguards are examined in a rigorous, methodical fashion for a variety of scenarios.  The primary focus is on prevention of the occurrence of a scenario.  The following gives examples of safeguards designed for prevention of a potential hazard.  Safeguards protecting against excessive pressure include high pressure alarms, pressure safety valves, thermal relief valves, piping/flange/equipment pressure ratings, water separation facilities and safety valves.  Safeguards protecting against excessive temperature include high temperature alarms, manual shutdowns and automatic shutdowns.  Safeguards protecting against low temperature include insulation and heating.  Excessive flow is protected against by high flow alarms, fail to safe position control valves, and pressure safety valves.  Safeguards against low flow or no flow include low flow alarms, recycle streams, shutdown systems and check valves.  High and low levels are protected against by high and low level alarms and shutdown systems.  Safeguards against contamination include use of analyzers, check valves and standardized utility connections.  Prevention safeguards against explosions include furnace instrumentation.  Loss of containment is protected against by isolation valves, proper material selection for corrosion and temperature, avoidance of dead legs, periodic inspection, proper water draw and sampling facility design, locked valves, proper design of pipe bracing and vent locations, freeze protection, proper pipe r

ating, emergency block valves and excess flow valves.  Safeguards for instrument failure include periodic testing of critical safety devices, including pressure safety valves.  Many of the safeguards mentioned above are automatic safety systems that are commonly referred to as interlocks.  In addition, process areas vent to the refinery flare safety system, which safely burns the flammable material.  

While the emphasis is on prevention of potential hazards, sometimes these events occur.  If this is the case, early detection is an important part of managing the event.  Examples of safeguards addressing detection of the occurrence of a potential scenario are discussed as follows.  Process and storage areas have leak detection systems for hydrocarbons, Hydrogen Sulfide and Ammonia.  Mitigation of an event is also an important part of managing the event.  Examples of safeguards addressing mitigation of potential scenarios are discussed as follows.  Safeguards to prevent escalation of incident include emergency block valves, depressurizing, equipment spacing, dikes, curbs and sewers, fire fighting access, hydrants, monitors, deluge systems, proper fireproofing of vessels, proper pipe supports and critical instrument controls.  As part of safeguarding against escalation of an event, the refinery has a comprehensive emergency response program.  Please refer to the emergency response section for a detailed discussion.

The refinery has a written Employee Participation Plan that addresses all of the Risk Management Program elements.  It is the policy to

n engineered and reviewed per MOC requirements, performance of inspections and tests to verify that construction and installation have been performed according to design specification, confirmation that changes have been communicated to appropriate personnel, confirmation that procedures and other documentation have been prepared and reviewed,  confirmation that any PHA start-up recommendations from the PHA performed for the MOC have been resolved, confirmation that applicable training has been performed and a confirmation that necessary support and emergency response systems are in place.  All new processes and changes to processes must follow the Engineering Standards Manual; inspections and tests are performed for verification.  Redlined copies of P&IDs are placed in the control room prior to start-up.  All operating, maintenance and emergency response procedures changes must be addressed prior to unit start-up.  Employee training on the change typically takes place at safety meetings or one-on-one meetings with the supervisor.  In addition, control rooms have MOC binders for operators to read as part of the shift change routine.  If changes involve procedures, supervisors are responsible for ensuring that their employees are trained and understand the new procedure.  This may involve one-on-one discussions or practical demonstration.  PSSR records are retained with MOC records.  Any recommendations from the MOC/PSSR process are tracked through a database. At this time, new or modified equipment may be started up or placed into service.  

Compliance Audits

Federal, state and local regulations require that employers audit their compliance at least once every three years, at least one knowledgeable person in the process must conduct the audit, and a report must be developed.  A system for tracking the audit findings must be d

eveloped and implemented.  These regulations also require that the last two compliance audit reports must be retained.

The purpose of the Compliance Audit Program is to determine the status and effectiveness of the Risk Management Programs established to meet the regulatory requirements of the Process Safety and Risk Management Regulations.  The Compliance Audit program is beneficial to accidental release prevention because the objective of the program is to assess existing Risk Management Programs and to find ways to improve the programs.  

The refinery has conducted Compliance Audits at least every three years since the implementation of OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard.  The two most recent audits were in 209 and 2012.  Each audit lasted approximately one week and reviewed all of the Risk Management Programs.  The Compliance Audit methodology utilized was a Tesoro Corporate checklist with is based on the Federal OSHA's Program Quality Verification (PQV) method and also includes OSHA's National Emphasis Program (NEP).  PQV method consists of evaluating the program, comparing the quality of the program with others in the industry and finally, verifying the implementation of each program.  PQV type audits are accomplished by conducting reviews of records, interviewing employees and conducting field observations.  

Compliance Audit team members are chosen based upon their knowledge and experience.  The final team will have members with knowledge and experience in refinery processing, regulatory requirements, and compliance auditing.  The audit team leader has experience both in refinery processes and auditing methodology.  Past audit teams have consisted of a mix of refinery personnel from other sites and personnel from Corporate Headquarters.  The most recent audit also employed outside consultants to conduct the compliance audit.

Findings from the Compliance Audits are written as a final report.  Corrections of the findings are assigned to pers

onnel in pertinent areas; a date for completion of the action is also assigned.  The findings and their corrective actions are tracked in databases maintained by the Health and Safety department.  (This database system also tracks findings from other types of audits and incident investigations.)  Minimally, the last two compliance audits are retained in the filing system.

Incident Investigation

Federal, state and local regulations require the development and implementation of an incident investigation program that addresses investigations for incidents which resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  In addition, local regulations require the conduct of a Root Cause Analysis for all Major Chemical Accidents or Releases.

The refinery has an Incident Investigation program that establishes uniform procedures for reporting and investigating accidents and near misses at the refinery.  An incident is defined as an accident or near miss.  The program focuses on determining the facts surrounding the incident and formulating corrective actions to prevent similar incidents from recurring.  The Incident Investigation program is beneficial to accidental release prevention because corrective actions are generated during investigations to prevent the incident from occurring again.

The Incident Investigation program classifies incidents into three categories, minor, serious and major (see classification in table below). Minor level incidents are investigated by an Area Supervisor using a causal factor approach to determine the cause of the incident.  Serious and major incidents are investigated by multi-disciplinary teams using Root Cause Analysis methodology.

Fire truck pumps and stationary pumps are performance tested annually for flow rates.  

Permanent gas detectors for Hydrogen Sulfide and Ammonia are located in the relevant process areas.  For example, there is an ammonia detector at the Chemical Plant near the ammonia storage area.  Permanent hydrocarbon gas detectors are also located in applicable areas of the refinery.  In addition, there are Ground Level Monitors (GLMs), required by BAAQMD, for Hydrogen Sulfide and Sulfur Dioxide.  There are three monitors for each chemical in four different potential downwind locations.  In addition, during an emergency, the refinery can dispatch personnel to perform real time monitoring of the community for any of the following:  Hydrogen Sulfide, Ammonia, Sulfuric Acid, Sulfur Dioxide, respirable  particulate matter, and total hydrocarbon concentration.  Refinery personnel may also use summa canisters to collect airborne samples if desired.  The refinery may also dispatch the Odor Science and Engineering Contractor to determine if any odors are occurring offsite.

Coordination

The refinery is an active member of CAER.  CAER is a nonprofit group comprised of industry, agency and community members that are dedicated to a safe and informed public.  CAER's core objectives are safe industrial facility operations, coordinated emergency response, providing an effective safety sharing forum and development of a trust-based relationship with the community.  CAER has several committees under its charter to accomplish these objectives.  The committees are:  personal safety, process safety, community outreach, emergency notification, emergency response preparedness and drill coordination, Petrochemical Mutual Aid Organization, and Industrial Hygiene.  Refinery personnel participate in all of the committees.

As part of CAER, the refinery participated in the development of the Community Warning System, a system to alert and inform the public about accidental releases of hazardou

s material.  Refinery personnel participated in the initial CWS education of the public about the CWS and Shelter-in-Place.  The refinery continues to be an active partner in the use of the CWS in order to provide early notification to neighboring communities about incidents that have the potential for offsite impacts.  

The Golden Eagle Refinery is a member of CAER's Petrochemical Mutual Aid Organization (PMAO) committee.  PMAO is an organization of industrial facilities and public agencies that focus on mutual aid response to emergencies.  The members of PMAO provide assistance (material and equipment) to any member requiring aid during an emergency situation.  The refinery may request assistance from PMAO during an emergency or refinery personnel may be part of a response at another facility as part of PMAO.  Some of the PMAO membership includes:  Tesoro, ConocoPhillips, DOW Chemical, Chevron, Valero, Shell, and Rhodia.  Agencies, including Contra Costa Health Services (CCHS), Rodeo/Hercules Fire Department, Contra Costa Emergency Medical Services (EMS), Contra Costa Fire Protection District, American Medical Response (AMR), U.S. Coast Guard, and the Richmond Fire Department, also attend PMAO meetings.  PMAO is dispatched through the Chevron Refinery Fire Department or DOW Chemical.  


Planned Changes to Improve Safety


The Golden Eagle Refinery continues to upgrade the refinery with planned changes to improve safety.  The projects selected for inclusion on this list provide significant reduction in the potential for catastrophic releases due to design changes, inventory reduction, equipment replacement and/or the project provides increased capability to respond to a catastrophic event.

Continuing upgrades to the Refinery Infrastructure.  As part of a project to improve refinery infrastructure, old refinery tankage and pipeways are being removed/upgraded.  New tanks and pipeways will be constructed to replace some of the old equipment.  However, the

re will be a net reduction in storage capacity at the refinery.  [This is an ongoing continuous improvement]

Seismic Study.  The refinery has had seismic studies performed on seven processes:  the Ammonia Recovery Unit (includes rail and storage), the Acid Plant, #5 Boiler Ammonia Injection (now demolished), #3 HDS, the DEA Stripper, the refrigerated Butane Storage Tank 691 and the Pressurized Butane Storage Spheres.  As part of the RMP resubmission, the process inventories for the refinery were recalculated.  As a result, an additional 12 units have been identified as requiring seismic study.  These units are:  #2 HDS, FCCU/#4 Gas Complex (2 units), Coker(DCU)/#5 Gas Complex (2 units), Alky Unit, Hydrocracker Complex (3 units), Propane Storage, Sulfur Recovery Unit (SRU) and Sour Naphtha Tank 318.  The previous studies listed seismic issues for each of the processes studied.  These seismic issues are the evaluated by the Engineering Department to determine recommendations for each issue.  For a more detailed discussion of the seismic studies, please refer to the Process Hazard Analysis section.  Seismic studies will be revalidated for previous units and performed initially for additional units during 2010. [This is an ongoing continuous improvement]

Facility Siting Study.  The refinery had a comprehensive Facility Siting Study performed on inhabited buildings throughout the refinery.  The study identified facility siting issues for the refinery.  A number of portable buildings have been relocated our of the process area.  Further action is currently under study by the Engineering Department to determine recommendations for the remaining identified issues.  For a more detailed discussion of the facility siting study, please refer to the Process Hazard Analysis section.  [This is an ongoing continuous improvement]

Refinery Safety Instrumented System (SIS) Upgrades.  Each SIS has been reviewed to evaluate the performance required.  The first stage of upgrades

to systems have been either completed or are in progress.  During the second stage, ongoing analyses are underway to find and correct any additional performance gaps.  [This is an ongoing continuous improvement]

Wharf upgrades.  Seismic upgrades are underway for both refinery wharves that would allow them to withstand a severe seismic event.  In addition, lighting, fire water systems and back up power systems will be upgraded.
